tests pass now. Will merge. And yes, I will pay attention to the next time it happens.

One thing @afchung and I wondered off list: This should only need minimal changes on the Driver side, right? Basically, it needs to change the Context and Task Configurations. Why is there this large number of changes to the Driver?

@markusweimer @afchung So here is what happened:

Earlier all group comm. configuration was added as part of context but since we decided to add in task I moved it to IMRU Driver. Then bugs from evaluator side started coming and all, so I added lots of logs and checks and added all Failure handlerds (IFailedEvaluator, IFailedContext, IFailedTask etc etc. Then on first pull request Julia suggested some unrelated changes and all. So it kept on changing.
if we feel code is in worse shape than before I can revert. Let me know.

As I mentioned on the JIRA, we should have a concise definition of what this test tests. Neither the JIRA, nor the commit message or the documentation in the code itself contain that information. This sets us up with a path to many overlapping tests. Specifically, it would be good to add an XML doc to the test class which clearly provides information that answers the following questions:
1. What functionality / methods / events of REEF are being tested.
2. In what cases does the test succeed?
3. In what cases does the test fail?
Is there a test that fails when the exception isn't propagated properly?
@afchung @markusweimer I have updated comments on both Jira and test.

LGTM, will test and merge

@afchung I have addressed your comments.

@jwang98052 Let's create a separate JIRA, with maybe an actual code example of how this should be done. I've used the same approach as for other injections in this code, but evidently they themselves are not done the right way.

I've done another pass and left some minor comments.

I am, however, confused about the locking policy in these classes. The code proposed here adds locks in every method of the state machine class. This makes sure that the internal state of the state machine is consistent at all times. In isolation, this class is thread safe, which is a good thing.

However, I also expect the IMRU Driver to make decisions based on this state, and those decisions will require locking. It would be natural to lock on the state machine object itself.

If we enforce such a policy, we end up with redundant locks: All accesses to the state machine are locked on the state machine object on the caller site, and then locked again inside the state machine. In java, we usually avoid such double locks by synchronizing on `this` inside the class. That way, we at least don't have two locks in play.

So, I have two questions from this analysis:
1. Is locking on `this` an accepted C# idiom?
2. Do we need this class to be thread safe at all, given that it will be used in a thread safe manner?

> @jwang98052 may want to close this PR first.

+1 on only discussing one of these related pull requests at a time. Many comments are redundant between the two. Let's get one in first, and then do the second state machine based on that design.

I've left some more comments. Basically, we need more robust test reporting from the Evaluator to the Driver to the unit test runner. Throwing anonymous instances of `Exception` makes it too easy to mistake a big in REEF for a successful test run.

I didn't get time to review the code while the PR has been merged and closed. I understand the PR was to resolve the deprecation issue. However, there are a few things we need to address properly after looking at the code:
- Network service should be properly injected with existing injector if possible. Given there are so many bindVolatileInstance, that tells me those objects should be already in the existing injector. 
- If any new binding is required, such as LoggingEventHandler, it should be set as part of the driver configuration. Or default should be set/applied. 
- In test code, we should create proper configuration for injecting NetworkService instead of using bindVolatileInstance
- If additional configuration is added for a forkInjector, it should be bound to a new configuration and use that configuration when calling forkInjector(). Binding with bindVolatileInstance is not recommended unless we have to reuse an existing object. 

I would suggest to create a new JIRA to fix the issue.

@markusweimer @jwang98052  I agree with what Markus wrote and raised similar sort of concerns on the JIRA myself. I would tend towards assuming that access to these state machines as well as the one for the tasks will be synchronized by the driver and hence these machines can be assumed to be accessed by one thread at a time and hence do not need locks. According to me otherwise debugging race conditions can easily become a nightmare.
@afchung Added missing licenses. Sorry about that. I will rebase post PR.
@afchung rebased
I've done another pass, mostly focusing on potential simplifications of the code.

C# doesn't have synchronized  method .

In terms of the lock, we always have two choices, one is to require caller to lock, the other is to provide a thread safety state machine. For now, I would prefer to write a thread safety state machine to ensure the state is managed in a central and unique place with thread safe manner. That would make caller code easy and no need to repeat the lock everywhere. 

When we write caller code, we will see the usage and revisit this logic if necessary. For now, I would just like to make sure the state machine is thread safe.

@markusweimer for folder structure there are two options:
1. put both system and task state machines under Org.Apache.REEF.IMRU.OnREEF.StateMachine
2. put system state machine in Org.Apache.REEF.IMRU.OnREEF.Driver.StateMachine and task state machine in Org.Apache.REEF.IMRU.OnREEF.IMRUTask.StateMachine

I would prefer the first one as both state machines will have a template to share, and may be more stuff to share later. And it would be easy to move the entire folder if we want to get it out of IMRU someday.

@afchung It looks fine now. Jenkins failed but it looks unrelated (in Tang), also I cannot understand why it failed, couldn't find any test failures.

Regarding the _locking strategy_:

> That would make caller code easy and no need to repeat the lock everywhere. 

That isn't actually achieved when we have a thread safe state machine. The caller code needs locks in itself. Consider receiving an `IFailedTask`: We'd have to know for sure whether we are expecting it. Which requires a lock across all the event handlers in the IMRU Driver. If we have that lock, it is immaterial whether or not the state machine itself is threadsafe from a correctness perspective. It matters, however, from a performance perspective. Also, declaring the state machine thread safe might mislead us into not having proper locks in the Driver.

If we absolutely must have a thread safe Driver state machine for other uses, we should at least get rid of the enforced double locking. Which brings me to:

> C# doesn't have synchronized method.

Yes, but can we use `this` as the lock, e.g. `lock(this)`? That would get the equivalent of `synchronized` methods, and also only one lock.

Regarding the _name space_ structure:

Both of these state machines are used in the driver exclusively. Hence  `Org.Apache.REEF.IMRU.OnREEF.IMRUTask.StateMachine` is misleading. The most specific namespace for them would be somewhere in `Org.Apache.REEF.IMRU.OnREEF.Driver`, e.g. `Org.Apache.REEF.IMRU.OnREEF.Driver.StateMachine`
LGTM.
Tried to review, but stopped as the code keeps changing. Please let me know when it is safe to review or close the PR until such time.
This adds a new schema for the failed task. Is that necessary? The underlying Evaluator-Driver protocol already has fields to carry a serialized exception.
@shulmanb done with a first pass.
Done with a first pass, mostly questions :)
@tcNickolas would be great if you can have a pass as well.

For the lock, let's take Dictionary as an example, we can use normal Dictionary in our code, apply lock whenever we need to access it. Or we can use ConcurrentDictionay that itself is thread safe, the caller doesn't need to worry about the lock. Either way should work, depend on the design and we will need to lock in one way or another.  

In current IMRU code, we use ConcurrentBag for _completedTasks and ConcurrentStack for _taskIdStack, then in the code, we don't need to apply lock any more. We use HashSet for _failedEvaluators, then the lock must be applied whenever it is used. 

If we assume there will be a big lock that locks all the code in handlers in the driver, then I would agree if we want to lock at caller side, we shouldn't use any ConcurrentBag, ConcurrentStack, just normal collections and not to lock state machine. But look at most of our drivers, including IMRUDriver, we don't have a big lock in handlers. 

Do we wan to have a big lock in each handler? I am little bit worry about the performance. The bigger the lock scope is, others thread would have to wait longer. For example, in ServiceAndContextConfigurationProvider, we use one lock to lock both _failedEvaluators and _submittedEvaluators, (I know the code is going to change so didn't comment on it). I fee that is not efficient. They should be locked separately. Or if the collections are thread safe, then we don't need to worry about it. Correct?
@afchung , @markusweimer Uploaded fixes for Andrew's comments.

I have made the following changes:
- Move the StateMachine under IMRU.OnREEF.Driver
- Move SystemStateTransitionException in the same folder as it doesn't make sense for it to be under OnREEF and it is about StateMachine. 
- Change MoveNext() in SystemStateMachine not to call GetNext() to avoid double lock.
- As Exceptions folder is removed in IMRU.OnREEF, the changes in other classes about Exceptions reference are recovered as before.

I agree driver needs to be thread safe. Question is shall we lock(this) at every handler? 
If we do, does that means we don't need to use any concurrent collections in the driver?

In the example above, there are some other operations like Get(key) + 1 are not locked rather than dictionary itself. 

If we lock individual data, we need to be very careful for each instance variable that may cause thread unsafe. If we lock(this) in driver handler, yes, it would be simple and safer. Any performance issue if we have 1000 evaluators and each sending multiple events?

If you look at current IMRU code also for submitting active context in any case is sequential since the handlers wait on lock inside ServiceAndConfigurationProvider. For task submission we first collect all configurations and then put in task starter before starting them. In my opinion generating these configurations etc. should not be too costly to cause any time issues. In real applications with data, events should come in scattered fashion any ways because of variability associated with data downloading in each mapper/partition.

If we want to add lock(this) in every handler at driver, that would impact other code in the fault tolerant work like Task Manager, Context Manager. Most possibly they will wrap some collections and responsible for adding/removing and updating states. To avoid double lock, we would have no lock for any of those collections and we will remove all the locks in current ServiceAndContextConfigurationProvider class.
I think this should be a separate discussion. Remove locks from the state machine is very easy if we decide to do so. We should not block ourselves because of it.

> To avoid double lock, we would have no lock for any of those collections

Exactly. We should have _one_ lock for status updates in the Driver. In similar code in the Java Evaluator, we used the state machine object itself as such a lock. Hence, I am not suggesting `lock(this)` in the Driver. If we must have a lock in the state machine, that lock should be `lock(this)`. That way, the driver and the body of the state machine methods can share the same lock, and we avoid double-locking.

@markusweimer answering your earlier question, `lock(this)` is widely used, but is actually advised against because it's possible that another thread also grabs a lock on the same object. The best practice is to create a `private object _lock = new object()` used only for locking.
@markusweimer I have addressed all of your comments. Please have a look.
The number of comments and LOC in the change makes me feel this should have been split into multiple PRs. I would suggest to break things into multiple smaller PRs in the future.

Interesting. How does one create synchronization between different objects in C#? In Java, we used a shared lock object for this, which seems to be discouraged in C#, where locks [should be `private` to the class that uses them](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/251391/why-is-lockthis-bad).

There are several exceptions logged which I'm a bit concerned about.
1. In evaluator log,
   `Org.Apache.REEF.Common.Tasks.Exceptions.TaskCloseHandlerNotBoundException: No EventHandler<CloseEvent> registered.` 
   Is it a problem if task doesn't have `CloseEvent` handler?
2. In driver log, 
   `org.apache.reef.exception.EvaluatorException: java.lang.Exception: Exception sent, but can't be deserialized`
   Does it mean we need to define PoisonException in some special way for it to be serializable?
Please fix Travis CI build failure

@markusweimer This is necessary without changing the Java `FailedTask` contract because the the Java Driver tries to deserialize the `Exception` into a Java `Exception` before passing it on to the C# Driver. If the `Exception` is a C# `Exception`, Java will simply throw the information away since it's not deserializable. This PR tunnels the Exception and other info through `FailedTask.data` in Java.
@tcNickolas Should be fine now.

I see. We probably need to add a `CloseEvent` handler to tasks which we know are going to get shut down. But I can do this in REEF-1304

From test behavior point of view, this change looks good to me.

@afchung sure! In the Java Evaluator, we want to make sure that the heartbeats sent to the Driver are consistent. However, we have many places that could trigger them from several threads. Hence, we need to coordinate.

The way we do it is via the `HeartbeatManager`. That is a singleton object that generates the heartbeats. All the relevant parts of the Evaluator have the instance of that type injected. They `synchronize` on that instance, which I believe is the same thing as to `lock` on an object in C#. All methods in that class are `synchronized` for good measure. That is the equivalent of wrapping the whole method body in `lock(this){...}` in C#.
This LGTM now. I assume you tested it on YARN?
I completed a pass.
Done with another pass.

Right, but then we have two locks: `_lock` in the state machine, and the state machine itself as the lock for everyone else.

I'd be in favor of removing `_lock` in the state machine and declare it not thread safe. All access to it would be guarded by locks on the call site anyhow. The lock inside the the state machine doesn't add anything from a correctness perspective, as far as I can tell.
